item.title: Over half of known human pathogenic diseases can be aggravated by climate change
item.content:encoded:
Nature Climate Change, Published online: 08 August 2022; doi:10.1038/s41558-022-01426-1

A systematic review shows that >58% of infectious diseases confronted by humanity, via 1,006 unique pathways, have at some point been affected by climatic hazards sensitive to GHGs. These results highlight the mounting challenge for adaption and the urgent need to reduce GHG emissions.
item.dc:title: Over half of known human pathogenic diseases can be aggravated by climate change
item.dc:creator: Camilo Mora

item.title: Big homes hinder emission cuts
item.content:encoded:
Nature Climate Change, Published online: 02 August 2022; doi:10.1038/s41558-022-01434-1

US homes are large by any international standards. Full grid decarbonization and electrification of residential energy uses — along with extensive house renovation — are all required, but smaller homes could make this much easier to deliver.
item.dc:title: Big homes hinder emission cuts
item.dc:creator: André Cabrera Serrenho
item.dc:source: Nature Climate Change, Published online: 2022-08-02; | doi:10.1038/s41558-022-01434-1

item.title: Heating up
item.content:encoded:
Nature Climate Change, Published online: 02 August 2022; doi:10.1038/s41558-022-01462-x

Each year weather records are being broken around the globe; this boreal summer has seen heat records fall across Europe, America and Central Asia. These discernible effects of climate change cannot be ignored, as combined with global issues they endanger society and well-being.
item.dc:title: Heating up
item.dc:source: Nature Climate Change, Published online: 2022-08-02; | doi:10.1038/s41558-022-01462-x
